clues.text: Octopuses have 3 of these: 2 send blood to the gills, one sends blood to the rest of the body
In 2023 British police foiled a plan by thieves to poach 200,000 Creme Eggs from this chocolatier
Noodling, a sport involving catching these barehanded, officially became legal in Louisiana in 2022
A house known as "The One" sold for $126 million (down from $295 mil.) in this area of "lovely atmosphere" next to Beverly Hills
The Apollo 11 astronauts had to declare Moon rocks to this government service upon returning to Earth
Socrates spent his last hours in an Athenian jail awaiting a cup of this poison
For an "affront to religion & common decency", this famous lover was arrested in Venice in 1755 & imprisoned in the doge's palace
In 1919 he came up with a scheme regarding postal reply coupons & would later offer investors 50% interest in 45 days
This inventor who struggled to cash in on his vulcanization of rubber did time in debtor's prison in Philadelphia, Boston & Paris
In 1898 this "Gift of the Magi" author spent time in the pokey for embezzlement of bank funds
Harvard's Widener Library honors Harry Elkins Widener, whose rare works were donated after his death in this maritime disaster
When this big-box retailer moved out, McAllen, Texas moved in to create a 123,000-square-foot public library, complete with a cafe
In March 1889 the first American library endowed by this philanthropist opened in Braddock, Pennsylvania
The Haskell Free Library straddles the U.S. & Canada--the front door is in Vermont; the circulation desk, in this province
In 1996 this library moved its main branch from the Mazarin Palace on the rue de Richelieu to a new facility along the Seine

March 1, 1781: Finally!
The states fully ratified this document! No way it isn't a document guiding U.S. democracy forever!

Oooof, this year: Matthew Flinders died.
The White House, set on fire. 1,200 killed by the Philippines' Mayon volcano eruption
Dec. 29, 1170: Will no one rid me of this meddlesome priest?!  I'm Henry II, for heaven's sake!  You did?  OK, awkward
July 28, 1794: Hold up, he dominated the Committee of Public Safety!  Guillotine?!  You just can't do that to this guy!  Oh... I guess you can
1494: This business league is comin' apart, man!  Ivan III nixed Novgorod from being one of its kontors, or trading posts
It's how Caesar supposedly said, "I came, I saw, I conquered"
Meaning "from the latter" & used of inductive reasoning, it's contrasted with "a priori"
Heard in courtrooms, it's Latin for "elsewhere"
This type of argument is directed against a person, not the facts in dispute
Want to start a war?  You'd better have this 2-word justification
"All hope abandon, ye who enter here" appears in this medieval poem
Poe's short story "The Murders" here marked the first appearance of the French detective C. Auguste Dupin
Lewis Carroll was the pen name of this mathematician turned children's author
A letter this author began writing to her grandfather evolved into her first novel "The House of the Spirits"
Created by Edith Pargeter, this monk solves crimes in the Middle Ages in mysteries like "The Leper of Saint Giles"
This verb can mean to view a movie, or to hide something from view, perhaps with a partition
To do this in the U.K. is to discuss a topic at a meeting; to do it in the U.S. is to postpone discussing it
To split a diamond with a sharp instrument, or to cling to someone very closely
You can ask for one of these if you wish to delay a trial, but it can also refer to just going on with the trial
An expression of regret for one's actions, or a defense like the one "of the Augsburg Confession"
Naturally, in "Foreign Correspondent", Joel McCrea wore this coat with a name from World War I
The U.S. Navy issued these, double-breasted, hip-length & dark blue, to new recruits until 2019
In 2019 this iconic star said a red coat she wore to protest the dangers of climate change will be the last clothing item she buys
This Scottish chemist invented a waterproof material that was used to make a raincoat that bears his name
Similar to a parka, this hooded jacket gets its name in part from Greenlandic Inuit

rounds.comments: (Ken: You'll give us the title of the play in each case.)

clues.text: Your wife asks for a divorce; lose direction in life; move in with sportswriter pal; clean his place.  Clean it again.  & again
Travel to Elsinore; glean what afflicts old pal Hamlet; try to find where he put Polonius; get betrayed; win 1968 Tony
Play affair card with a guy, then accuse his wife of witchcraft; roll again & accuse her of attempted murder
Advance to Harry Hope's bar; lose turn waiting for Hickey; play your pipe dream card; chill at bar after Hickey is arrested
Teach evolution to your science class; get arrested; be prosecuted by a 3-time presidential candidate; guilty card, pay $100
Oddly, Leeds Castle in England houses a museum devoted to 5 centuries of this canine neckwear
In Milwaukee spring on over to the National Hall of Fame & Museum for these collectible dolls, sometimes called "nodders"
Like Las Vegas, Warsaw, Poland has this type of museum that's really lit (literally)
Cup Noodles Museum in Osaka honors Momofuku Ando, who invented instant ramen & founded this company that makes it
Croatia, which broke up with Yugoslavia in 1991, has a Museum of Broken Relationships in this capital city
For not complying with a court order in 1995, a Philly lawyer was jailed for this; he kept not complying & was in jail for 14 years
Be an upright citizen & know it's the legal right to bring a lawsuit; judges decide if you have it so the case can proceed
A defense that involves claiming one knew nothing, saw nothing & heard nothing is named for this "Hogan's Heroes" character
Your Honor, the defendant is incompetent, or if I may get fancy, this 3-word phrase, Latin for "not master of one's mind"
I cite 1963's him v. Wainwright--the 6th Amendment's right to counsel extends to felony defendants in state courts
The last advertising idea conceived by Don Draper on "Mad Men" was for this bubbly product
It's the 2-word name of the menacing parallel dimension on "Stranger Things"
At the end of "Game of Thrones", this member of the Stark family becomes the ruler of Westeros
"There's no such thing as real psychics", proclaimed Simon Baker as Patrick Jane on this drama
As Baba Voss, this actor stars in "See", a series about a dystopian future where most of humanity has lost its sight

rounds.text: The last film Cecil B. De Mille directed, it was a partial remake of a silent epic he'd directed 33 years before
